# Read Tester

Simple program for anyone writing a filesystem or playing with the kernel read
code and wanting to make sure that the different read entry points are
returning consistent data and not corrupting data on the way back to userspace.

## Example

```bash
$ ./reader /bin/ls
File: /bin/ls
Using read()
Open Flags:
Seek offset into file 0 byte(s).
Reads will happen in a block size of 4096 byte(s).
00000000:00004096:f7ac47a69337298acd0596a760a4aeb9
00004096:00004096:a6fd977f281163e1c5b599dcccf7f9da
00008192:00004096:837c5d0a2f9679b9fc6c77b91c208ce7
00012288:00004096:285326bad209e1485fb68e1b04de5668
00016384:00004096:ec85bf1257b86c9a095a09c2f6cf7dc1
00020480:00004096:0e7fd8c14921cc0cdd9ead7ca63c3a5c
00024576:00004096:6f9e4d18d0b8728746cb8d158af768d2
00028672:00004096:bee51125eaacd72936b834fdf98361a6
00032768:00004096:7a96b0d44ad1df3f29cb79403649123f
00036864:00004096:3c524565835d0f159b702b346b8d8bc2
00040960:00004096:d1364fcb055ea9874f6aa8a0d8a57a96
00045056:00004096:0169332776ff4502d435bb50a281e983
00049152:00004096:6f907f416ce4561c33f445a10d00f8bc
00053248:00004096:827206caa42b00a1c2781baa11cbbc62
00057344:00004096:4520217b9778ee44da421dfa7b62558f
00061440:00004096:5907462dd905d9511ba54b7afbe78940
00065536:00004096:017170811baea9e5ba5f8d6b20aa3f23
00069632:00004096:b162c34bda415607f95f6d1d131792ca
00073728:00004096:17338afcda3157186a51273ce6dabfca
00077824:00004096:73a02651e0e680a99ebc3a7ec89a270a
00081920:00004096:2c213ca1d50a8e422c34cce31640b935
00086016:00004096:2bd33cd7d01b39cf766903d4ec75e820
00090112:00004096:b4e230b864574bdda656a154a557e90d
00094208:00004096:76638cfb32cf279ba8308dc8f96699f4
00098304:00004096:8cf164e5e7c9f0fe4df356e03a26da58
00102400:00004096:ccb1c54657e25e04997f1f1476f2375e
00106496:00004096:042112ceece4ae7cdbc5a441503c70d7
00110592:00004096:3f5d2ce8da900477dfa6a1f9f37fbe5c
00114688:00003536:438ec3cf19c1913089435a2643abc4e3
00118224:00000000:d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e
   final:00118224:8cca25341f472b475c5915f1d4c47e3b
```

## Usage

```
usage: reader [-n | -v | -d | -m] [-b SIZE] [-s SIZE] FILENAME

  -n         use read() calls
  -v         use readv() calls
  -d         use read() calls but open the file with O_DIRECT
  -m         use mmap() and read chunks from the mapped region
  -b SIZE    read in SIZE chunks
  -s SIZE    seek SIZE into the file before reading
```
